evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was observed and documented during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25, as recorded in the hist_dynamic_und_t2_interim dataset.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew is supported by consistent evidence in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_dynamic_und_t2_interim records, with no contradictory data undermining this root cause.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features of human factors and crew resource management issues identified in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_dynamic_und_t2_interim data.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was observed and documented during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25, as recorded in the hist_dynamic_und_t2_interim dataset.

defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination among crew during the event
If mechanical faults were documented that explain the incident
If procedural deviations were clearly identified as primary cause

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8 directly documents lack of warning signals and communication failures among crew; H2 and H3 show coordination attempts and changes in control, supporting observed communication breakdown. Discriminators favor communication breakdown over procedural deviation or mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in interpreting whether communication failure or procedural deviation was primary cause

slot_statements.availability: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and observable within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the 12-25 hist_dynamic_und_t2_interim phase.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identified procedural deviation in pushback execution withstands scrutiny against potential counterarguments or alternative explanations within the context of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_dynamic_und_t2_interim data.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The procedural deviation aligns with key features identified in the pushback process of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA, reflecting deviations from standard operating procedures during the specified timeframe.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and observable within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the 12-25 hist_dynamic_und_t2_interim phase.

assumptions: The TRP markings were visible and adequate as per H7 description.
The trainee and instructor statements accurately reflect the situation.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP markings were obscured or inadequate, or if the trainee was untrained or unaware of the TRP, this would challenge the procedural deviation claim.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 documents the procedural deviation with the aircraft passing the TRP and hitting the blast barrier. H8 and H9 support that the deviation was procedural, not due to environmental marking deficiency, as the trainee was trained and the visual signals were inadequate.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence of marking visibility or environmental conditions; reliance on instructor and trainee statements.

assumptions: The TRP markings were visible and adequate as per H7 description.
The trainee and instructor statements accurately reflect the situation.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP markings were obscured or inadequate, or if the trainee was untrained or unaware of the TRP, this would challenge the procedural deviation claim.

H8 and H9 support that the deviation was procedural, not due to environmental marking deficiency, as the trainee was trained and the visual signals were inadequate.
availability.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence of marking visibility or environmental conditions; reliance on instructor and trainee statements.

If procedural deviations were clearly identified as primary cause
